commentBody: Yeah, 48D is clever...hilarious, even.  I'm still in awe...
I solved it without understanding the theme. I just knew each starred clue had a metal in the answer. Didn't quite realize you had to read over the metal though

Clever and fun, but seemed easy for a Thursday. 

L

Excellent puzzle. It nice to see an appearance by the criminally underrated Paul Pena, who wrote Jet Airliner. Steve Miller's version was great but Pena's original is better: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cjr5U7g6aiA

Great Thursday puzzle.

9/10.

Breezy 25 mins without understanding the theme. I only figured out that the asterisks answers contained a metal, but didn't make the connection that the clues actually makes sense when you remove the metal from the answer. I thought GROWINGOLD was GROWINGOut at first, and THEIRONY containing the pronoun THEIR only added to my initial confusion.

I disagree that zero-sum game is a good clue for WASH. A wash implies a player ended up where they started, not that the sum total of all wins and losses among all players was zero, with individuals gaining or losing.

Poker (if no casino is taking a rake) is always a zero-sum game. It is rarely a wash.

This weeks Thursday: I DID IT! That was a clever trick.  

I was prepared for a rebus, but when I got to SCRAP METAL and LATINOS, the way was PAVEd to get ‘er done. 

Learned something new.  And how is Alaska not the right answer? How is it Nevada? I was truly expecting it to be Alaska.

Some nice wordsmithing in the theme answers and some fun clues.  I got the theme only from the revealer.  It took me a good while to get COOS partly because I’ve never photoshopped anything and   hadn’t yet come up with TIPS as the punny answer. I tried moos for way longer than I should have.

I balked a bit at DIDOK for got a cee.  That wasn’t the rule in my house when I was growing up, although my dad did make an exception for penmanship, about which he didn’t care.  Even Bs were dubious in his book.

really enjoyable theme today - LATINOS is where it clicked for me

Initially I had CLIPPY in place of NEOPET. There are quite a few 2000s virtual companions to choose from there. My favorites were WEBKINZ but sadly those have yet to appear in a crossword. One day!

-----
jackie n shadow 4ever
UNIX was in and out twice sigh. CROP is available in any photo editing app/program. CLONE I haven’t seen outside of Photoshop yet :)

So very Thursday. I  had so many cavities as a kid you'd have thought my teeth really did GROW IN GOLD, made sense to me.

Loved seeing Dari & gari, very rare in a puzzle those two, and Lydia Oh Lydia!*  And yes, we are so dead.  It's a wash.  We were busy helping our Latino brothers and sisters avoid The Clamp and meantime the sly dogs came to town like it was a Nevada casino, rolled down their ski hats, kicked the guards in their shins, took scads of prize money and fled -- to another venue to do the same thing, all the while singing how they're at war against corruption. The irony!

*But at least we can enjoy Groucho singing about Lydia:

Oh Lydia, oh Lydia, say have you met Lydia?
Lydia, the Tattooed Lady
She has eyes that folks adore so
And a torso even more so

Lydia, oh Lydia, that encyclopydia
Oh Lydia the Queen of Tattoo
On her back is the Battle of Waterloo
Beside it the wreck of the Hesperus, too
And proudly above waves the red, white, and blue
You can learn a lot from Lydia

When her robe is unfurled, she will show you the world
If you step up and tell her where
For a dime you can see Kankakee or Paris
Or Washington crossing the Delaware

Oh Lydia oh Lydia, say have you met Lydia?
Oh Lydia the Tattooed Lady
When her muscles start relaxin'
Up the hill comes Andrew Jackson

Lydia oh Lydia, that encyclopydia
Oh Lydia the queen of them all
For two bits she will do a mazurka in jazz
With a view of Niagara that nobody has
And on a clear day you can see Alcatraz
Easy for a Thursday. Seemed more like a Wednesday. Neat trick with the theme though. Finished in 30, I usually average 67.
Can I object to 29A? I read “personal pronoun” to mean “first-person pronoun.” Am I wrong?

I had a lot of fun with this one! Is it cheating to jump ahead to the revealer? I sure hope not; It all made sense fairly early for me. The upper right quadrant did slow me down a bit. Thursdays- the puzzles- are awesome! Too bad I don't have the patience to actually wait until Thursday to complete them. It makes Thursdays- the days- kind of anticlimactic.

Is it me, or was that the easiest Thursday in years? My Thursday average is around 26:31, but today 16:57. Confluence of the clues and my current knowledge? Maybe, just seemed too breezy for a Thursday.
Not Thursday tough, but fun nonetheless.   Didn’t we encounter we’re so dead  just recently ?
Is missing the theme a side effect of speed solving?

Awesome puzzle. I got the theme answer almost immediately but thought it meant I was supposed to have an answer including the metal, and then remove the metal to make the answer fit, which really confused me for awhile. Needed the first GROWING OLD hint to realize I had it the wrong way round. Honestly that answer was “growing” more obvious over time as I solved other clues, but somehow it still didn’t click that I had the theme backwards. My only fuss otherwise was that I had LESMIs initially which made MAZDA impossible to guess for some time. This was great thanks!

So in the mini - can someone please explain how CISCO suggests the Bay Area?

(Argh. As I typed that question, San FranCISCO popped into my head. So I get it now, but I think it's a horrible clue).

This was okay, although I found yesterday (Wednesday) both tougher and more fun.

Just me or does this theme seem a bit underdeveloped?  It seems so promising.

I didn't love some of the cluing, and things like "oh stop" felt weak, but a reasonable if unexciting Thursday.

At least this week overall is harder than last week (though marred by a weirdly harsh Tuesday).

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Deb: I'm too old for a puzzle the test my mettle like this one did. I'm way past metal age, so stop meddling with my thought processes like you usually do on Thursdays.

I struggled initially: the clues were not at all on my wavelength. However, as is often the case, I looked up the trivia to get more crosses, and that allowed me to complete the grid quite quickly.

The theme was OK. I liked that the themed entries were not gibberish before applying the trick to them. It would have been awesome if there were another layer of the theme connecting the entries before the metal was scrapped from them - but I suppose that would have been impossible to construct.

I've been eating sushi for decades yet I can't recall ever encountering the name for that pickled ginger. Maybe I'll remember it after today ("Suuuure," says my brain).

I only got how TIPS is a *punny* reply to "What are you waiting for?" as I was writing this comment, wanting to ask the community to explain the pun to me. Apparently I'm not very quick, but I'm terribly slow either 🤣. I have another question though. Serving staff are called servers now, not waiters. But is what they do still called waiting (on on somebody)? Or did that clue scrap modern lingo for the sake of the pun?

Loved it … even though I got hung up on NEVADA.

EASE before PAVE, which made CAPITA and DARI look formidably alien and stumped me into a baffled perplexity.

NASSUA? NESSUA? What US state has the highest percentage of federal land? The rest of it was amicable and uncomplicated fun.

Cheers

This puzzle will test your metal.

(Assay that one a lot.)

Because my first themer was 17A and I excitedly filled in LAosPDR for 37A (I've been! And it was very cool, partially because no one knows exactly what all the ancient jars were for) it took me a while to realize that the metal didn't have to be the end of the answer. I spent a few mins staring at LAos and trying to figure out a metal that would make sense. Overall enjoyed the puzzle and finished in a reasonable amount of time for a Thurs. And TIL about Lydia!

Strands Thread:


Strands #347
“It's in the cards”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵


No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button.  

Smooth.  

Let's acknowledge Christina Iverson who, along with Tracy Bennett, pens most of these puzzles.

Fun puzzle with a few bumps. PART before PAVE. many states before NEVADA. and can someone explain Top Seed Perks BYES? Thanks. 

Loved the clue for TIPS. AND THE THEMES WERE GREAT (once I figured out I didn’t have to know the chemical formula). 

TIL GARI, DARI and MAZDA. 

THANKS constructor, whose name I’ve forgotten. 😊😊
SCADS of good entries and a fun theme, so I don’t mind no rebus.

A not too difficult Thursday, for which I’m grateful as I seem to have woken up this morning with a stinker of a cold. Having to screw my eyes up to see the screen. Ugh.

Love the theme, which I finally got with GROWIN/GOLD. The rest was crunchy enough to make me think, but all doable from crosses. Lovely.

I do enjoy the wordplay grids, though found a lot of the non-wordplay clues in this one were very obscure so the whole thing felt tough.

Can’t help wonder why the wordplay clues make no mention of the actual words that go in as answers. Like, the gimmick is clear, and if you do as the gimmick clue tells you then the answers are pretty easy to arrive at, but then the literal words in the grid, that the constructors obviously worked to ensure were actual words, have nothing to link to them. Always feels slightly like a waste.

Not too tricky, but fun.  Extra points for Paul PENA.

I also liked that the metals moved over by one place with each answer.  GOLD was at the end, IRON was second from the end, and so on.  Just a nice little extra touch.

Whew. Typical long Thursday workout for me, and whole lot of working the crosses to figure out the theme answers. And... have to confess that I was just not getting the trick at all until I was almost done and stopped and pondered for a while. Just made for a nice 'aha' moment at the end. 

A couple of puzzle finds today. With my memory, I'm not entirely sure that I didn't ever notice these before, but... whatever. I'll go ahead and post them in replies. 

....
Magnet school focus at 49A and I confidently and quickly put in ARTS at 49A. Silly me, I am not keeping up with the times, STEM is the only thing that matters these days. And maybe not that any more.

Is there a maximal maxim for making the maximum from the minimum, Maxine, my Milanese mum? Or is my fear best allayed by an alloy of aluminum and aluminium forged by an alliance of aging alumni of my alma and pia maters, my mammalian mamma from Milan?

As is usually the case with Tricky Thursday's (or any other day for that matter) I'll just say to myself, "Yeah, something is happening here, but I don't know what it is" *.    Cruised along with partial fill on the themers until I got to the reveal and, "clang!", the penny dropped.   Well done and thanks. 

* When the Dylan movie screened here, every time a recognizable location in Cape May was shown everybody cheered.

Oh... have to add this. I looked at our constructor's page on Xword Info. This is his seventh puzzle, and only his second one with a theme - all the others were Friday or Saturday puzzles. But... his first ever puzzle was a Thursday from April 22, 2001 and was an amazing feat of construction. Many of us may have done this one (I'm pretty sure I did), but some may not be familiar with it. Anyway - that one had three theme answers, each just clued with a time span. e.g.: "*1962-67, 1971, 1983 :" SEANCONNERY The other two were: PIERCEBROSNAN DANIELCRAIG But then there were seven rebus squares in the puzzle, each of them just containing the letters: 'OO' And there was no hint as to that. So... OO? Seven? Get it? Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/22/2021 ....

CR Day 23:  ANNA

I Taught Myself To Live Simply

I taught myself to live simply and wisely,
to look at the sky and pray to God,
and to wander long before evening
to tire my superfluous worries.
When the burdocks rustle in the ravine
and the yellow-red rowanberry cluster droops
I compose happy verses
about life's decay, decay and beauty.
I come back. The fluffy cat
licks my palm, purrs so sweetly
and the fire flares bright
on the saw-mill turret by the lake.
Only the cry of a stork landing on the roof
occasionally breaks the silence.
If you knock on my door
I may not even hear.

- Anna Akhmatova 

CSD ™

Oh Jem, you SLY DOG…

Truly clever clueing, and
I sure do love completing a grid with
names ( and languages )
I did *not* know and seeing them
filled in by the crosses.

Like a free basket of knowledge nuggets
to put in my cap
and save for later!

 ⭐️

Not my finest hour (or 25 minutes)--I don't expect myself to know the names of 21st century starlets--even Emmy-award winning ones--but, given my interests in languages and food, DARI and GARI felt like things that should have been gimmes, but weren't. Although not a problem for me, I wonder how many solvers can pull a Latin third declension neuter plural off the top of their caput. And there have been so many kingdoms in the the long history of Asia minor, xYxIA could have been a lot of things (although I dismissed sYrIA pretty quickly). And SKxHxx suggested a headgear from a culture not mine--Arabic? Indian? Hebrew?--even thought I'm not planning to be bare-headed when I go skiing later this morning.

Also, unable to unwind the theme without the revealer (I know Lewis likes to challenge himself with that, as well)--GROW IN and GROWING OLD both have "grow" at their roots, and some people do sport GOLD teeth, although usually not from birth; and THEIR(s) seemed like a perfectly good pronoun to find in THE IRONY. 

Now that the puzzle is done, I will be frustrated all morning, trying to think of some common two-word phrase with the form xxxSIL VERxxx or xxxCOP PERxxx. Anyone? Or even xxxNEODYMI UMxxx. (Did you know that Neodymium [magnets] come [in bars]? Or that NEOPETS live in the Kingdom of Neopia? I do, now.)

(In case anyone should misread this post, my frustration is entirely with my own dimness, and not with any flaw in Mr. Burch's puzzle.)

For me, five no-knows to overcome, and that was sweet.  Even after all the years I’ve done crosswords, it still feels like a miracle when there’s an answer in the puzzle that I’ve never heard of AND I STILL GET IT!  

I also like what I need to do to get those no-knows.  Often, I have to leave the area where a no-know is and eventually circle my way back, and by the time I’ve returned there’s enough there to fill in what was once un-gettable real estate.  There’s magic in that too.

What I’m saying is that five no-knows in the box will spark my day.  It will satisfy my brain’s workout ethic and bring me the pleasure of conquering obstacles.  I know this will happen because it’s a Times puzzle, and almost always, IMO, Times puzzles are so well edited that difficult answers, even no-knows, are crossed appropriately.

So, thank you for including such answers in your puzzle, Jem, and gratitude to the NYT team for your dedication and expertise.

This on top of a clever never-before-done theme, created a splendid outing. Thank you, Jem, for making this!

Picturing a knight, paused on a mighty steed, sun glinting off a scrap of metal armour, clumsily unfolding his precious cheat-sheet detailing the known weaknesses of dragons. 

A fun questword.
And didn’t take a(n) bronzeage to solve it, either.
Almost had it ORE filled.I did it on my ComPEWTER.I will COPPER to a couple of mistakes on my part.

As someone else said, I found the theme and wordplay clues interesting and clever, (SOAP, EEL, PAVE) and COURT EVENT - was that law court, basketball court, Royal court, go courting? but so many of the other clues a complete mystery. It almost felt like a foreign language to me.
Cultural clash.
Didn't know or hadn't heard of
SCADS
WASH
WE'RE SO DEAD 
YA DIG
IHOP
BYES
IDOL
ANNA
TIPS (how is that a pun?)
You're too much
and slight confusion for me - "on" next, not UP NEXT
and "buckets" for PAILS!
The theme is really ingenious, but I spent so much time working around and about with crossers that I didn't really appreciate it. 
Carry on with the ESL classes!
Nice punning, Deb - I rate your efforts a tin.

Interesting theme. Somewhat remarkable to find enough thematic entries to make the theme work, and also to have entries of the right lengths to satisfy the constraints of symmetry. 

Nice fill too---very fine puzzle!
I do not understand why it's LATINOS. It's in Laos.

For those who do the Cryptogram -- there is an error in today's puzzle. 

The first word in the second row is typeset as IXH. 

The solution does not make sense unless you add a letter, to make it IXHC. 

At least, it does not make sense to me. I'm willing to be convinced otherwise.

I got GROWINGOLD first, but assumed that the rest of the "metal" answers would consist of the clue answer followed by the name of the metal, and I filled in LAos, etc., accordingly, which left me almost hopelessly jammed up. I finally broke down and looked up the Afghani language (my only lookup), which made ATWAR obvious, which revealed the error, and the whole thing crumbled pretty quickly.

That one guy in the photo looks too short for a stormtrooper...which brings up something that always bothered me about that line: If Luke Skywalker is too short to be a stormtrooper, then how did he find a stormtrooper who was wearing a set of armor that would fit him?

I can't wait to get to Mike's pun-o'-the-day...bound to be a...

I kept filling in spaces with the help of crossings, and each time it got more off-the-wall and off-topic.  Then I spotted all the metals...and THEN (belatedly) I saw (smelt?) that after the METAL was taken out, the clue was satisfied.

Language of Afghanistan.
Blind Blues Paul.
Ancient Asia Minor
Unknown Actor Person
Diety here, diety there  (one of which I certainly knew; one of which DHubby owned when I met him long, long ago)

OoooooKAY!  Mission Accomplished.  Heck of a job.
Deb, you've obviously been reading too many comments from Mike in Munster!

Fun, but a tad easy for a Thursday. Or maybe I just lucked out in that, literally last night, I was reading all about the Anatolian kingdom of Lydia. I wanted to know more, having just finished Colin McEvedy's book "Cities of the Classical World." 

An hour of Wikipedia rabbit-hole armchair research revealed that grammatical gender in Indo-European languages originally was "animate" and "inanimate" (maintained only in the branch that included Lydian), but then, to make it easier to understand which nouns went with which adjectives in speech, "animate" divided into "masculine" and "feminine," and took a bunch of inanimate nouns along with it....

But I digress. :)

I really like when I find the theme, then look back at a themed answer with only 1 to 3 letters filled in, then am able to figure it out just by thinking about it (in a reasonable time frame)

I did that TWICE today, with LATINOS and THE IRONY. Highly rewarding puzzle for me. Took me quite a bit longer than my Thursday record, but better than my (beginner-biased) average. Hats off to Jem Burch for a challenging but doable Thursday grid.
So the theme is that the answer doesn't make sense? Gotcha.

Did I ever know that MAZDAs were named after a God?
It seems like something I should have known, and there seems to be a vague shadow of a memory in there, but...

A Zoroastrian God???

Ah, but MAZDA is also related to its founder's name, Jujiro Matsuda.

Will this memory stick?
Genghis Blues is my favorite documentary ever. Thank you, Jem, for the reminder! It's definitely not what I think of in connection with the word "documentary." Just too wild to be believed.

Neatly done Thursday theme. Assumed Alaska (Ahh ok...by percentage, I can see NEVADA), and "eta" (Soooo much more common in the puzzled than ETD). Also didn't know GARI  - but I don't eat sushi. Knew it was WERESODEAD, but briefly considered "...cool". That middle bit was the last to fall.
Half of average, but I don't put much stock in my averages. I haam often pulled away with the puzzle up and running, and don't give it a thought when I'm working in the archives. 
Always happy with no look-ups, though.

I really enjoyed this.  Usually on a Thursday even with hints and comments I have to resort to autocheck and when really desperate, running the alphabet.  This one, a few helps and I got there!

A lot of times I'm done in by crossing entries that don't help me fill in particular areas but this one seemed to have a nice balance of crosses to more obscure (to me, anyway.). Not that I didn't have wrong answers that misled in places..

Before I knew the theme, THEYTHEM fit nicely and even though the mismatched tense bothered me, it matched the clue and the few crosses I had in place.  It wasn't until later when I sure couldn't find a metal in there that I erased some letters.  Oh, THEIRONY of the other fitting!

Anyway, I don't usually comment but wanted to say I really enjoyed today's puzzle.

I got a chuckle out of 26A, “Heads of Ancient Rome”.  Threw in senate and moved on. Got to 26D … say what now?

I lol’ed.
Hated it! Latinos is a country I grumpily asked? Then I peeked and came to love it. Maybe there is some hope.
damn, i was not on the same wavelength as the clues at all. left more frustrated than satisfied after completion but maybe it's just a me problem lol
Terrible. The themed entries can only be solved by crosses. Just awful.
Hrrmm, I don’t think 42A works, since a WASH would be a tie. This is not the meaning of a zero-sum game: a winner who takes all and a loser.

YADIG crossing with LYDIA and GARI? Oof. "Ya dig" sounds like something the guy who speaks "jive" in the movie Airplane would say . . . just ridiculously outdated and stereotyped jargon. 

Other than that, I thought it was a fun puzzle with a cute theme.
not to be that person, but couldn't technically it be Latinas/ah stop?  I know it's not the "best" answer but people do say ah vs. oh, do they not?

Got 44A of the themed clues first. Saw P...EAL.

Sat, confused.

Guessed 57A with only one cross.

Went back to 44A.

Sat, confused.

Light dawned eventually.

A puzzle full of clues that made me think and then made me laugh.

A theme so clever it snuck up on me until I slapped my forehead and said "of course!"

What's not to love? Some say it was too easy for a Thursday... some say it was too hard and they didn't get the theme.

I found it just right. 😊
I had some look ups because I couldn't get the theme and was really set on "they them" haha. I had to read the column to make it make sense 😅 today wasn't my day!

Like others have already mentioned, it took me a long time to get the theme. That said, things became much easier after that, and I went from "this is too hard for a Thursday" to "wow, this is really clever!"

I especially enjoyed 40A. I've been driving one for 8 years and never knew the origin of the name! 🤦‍♂️😄
Once again, solved it early, then had to wait for Wordplay to find out how clever I was (or it was).

It's occurred to me that I'm not taking the time to ponder the finer points of the puzzles. Oh sure, I'm solving them, but I'm missing a lot of the fun wordplay by just "doing the puzzle". My late New Year resolution is to go back and fix that, starting today. This one was too much fun to just solve and dash.
I was grateful for the explanation for 42A. I'd never heard of WASH in that sense - but I have now, so it's probably guaranteed never to arise again!

Enjoyable, but pretty easy for a Thursday. I solved this in 5.67 minutes under my average, but maybe I missed the theme slightly? Instead of thinking "scrap the metal" as Deb did, I thought of just "scrap metal" maybe because that has something to do with one of my hobbies that uses said. Anyway, I understood that the solver needed to remove the metal to make sense of the answer. Nice clueing throughout. 
Today's mini was fun!
Great puzzle! Loved it and solved 9 minutes better than Thursday  average. I’m looking forward to more from Jem—I dig!

I swim, I swam and I swum till I reached shore.

Neat theme but I never saw it till I went over the completed grid and realized the metals had to excluded to concur with the clue.

Good fun.
I may not be as grammatically competent as I thought... Having a mistake in 10A really messed up that whole corner for me. I was sure my mistake was anywhere but in 10A. I guess I need a refresher!

As others have said, it took me a while to get the clue because after GOLD, I was expecting it at the end and that wasn't working. After that was sorted out, I was stuck in the center right as I had ETA instead of ETD and SLYFOX for SLYDOG, so it was not pretty.
I was really not a fan of this one, not to say its' bad, but it just did not make any sense to me as I did it. Slower than my average for thursdays. boo :(

I dug this puzzle! I always love when there’s a theme and/or code. At first I thought it was “THEIR-ONY” which didn’t make sense but then I realized it was “THE-IRONY” and therefore I saw Gold, Lead, Iron, and Tin which can be scrapped. Thanks again! Have a Thrilling Thursday and Namaste!!
I love me some Thursday puzzlin!

I was a little dumb about the theme this time. I got SCRAPMETAL before I got any of the other theme clues, and immediately thought, okay, so metal is cut out of the answers. And then got GROWINGOLD and thought, oh, they just have metal in the answers. I don't really get how that works for teeth emerging though. And then proceeded to never apply any critical thinking to this.

I like this one. (Well, I like any I can solve, no matter how hard or  easy.) But I particularly like this one because many clues had more than one answer that could fit--eye vs pie, for example. One needed to reach a critical mass, but once attained, the answers fell in place.
Not a fan of these puzzles within puzzles. I'll wait for tomorrow.

Late puzzle find - maybe appropriate for today. Don't recall EVER seeing another one like this. Anyway - a Thursday from June 7, 2001 by Randolph Ross. The reveal in that one was at 5 across. The clue and answer: "Theme of this puzzle" BOARD And then all the theme answers had essentially the same clues. The clue for each of them was either: "Four before 5-across." or "Three before 5-across." And the theme answers: STARCUPLAPCARD BASERUNNINGFOOT CLAPSNOWDASHSEA HEADKEYSIDEWASH SKATESCOREPAST Can't imagine having much of a chance at that one. Would have been just a lot of working the down crosses for all those theme answers. And how many answers that end in BOARD are there that have ever been in puzzles? Well... 124. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/7/2001&g=3&d=D ...
Fun puzzle … and fairly easy for a Thursday (I consider any puzzle without a REBUS easy for me). 17A was my aha moment. Nice 👏👏👏

It would have made my month if PENA was clued as “Captain Beefheart poem recited by Jeff ‘Antennae Jimmy Semens’ Cotton on Trout Mask Replica” Here’s David Lynch reciting PENA: https://youtu.be/N-oyCE-nfc4 The puzzle was a struggle but I finally figured it out without lookups. The theme was okay but it would have been nice to find a sneaky way to tie in the actual fill with the clue.

Nice Thursday!

Speaking of tin, I just found out that Stannous Fluoride is fluoride bonded with tin. I had been wondering. Apparently it has anti-microbial properties unlike sodium fluoride. So when you see toothpaste marketed as being particularly good at killing bacteria under the gums, it probably has stannous fluoride instead of sodium fluoride.

And one more late puzzle find. Might have done this one but I don't recall it. Actually don't recall ever seeing another one quite like this. A Sunday from March 15, 2020 by Nancy Stark and Will Nediger with the title: "Ready, set...GETS LOW!" A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Hoot at an out-of-focus nature photograph?" BOOBLURREDBLUEBIRD "Antsy feeling when one is out of cellphone range?" SONERVOUSNOSERVICE "Landing in Rotterdam?" DUTCHTOWNTOUCHDOWN And the other theme answers: ALLHAILHALLALE BCHORDKEYBOARD STEVEDOREDIVASTORE Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/15/2020&g=114&d=A ....
Just right.
Fun puzzle! Agreed with the constructor that the "Genghis Blues" documentary about singer Paul PENA is a great watch.
Oof

Great puzzle, thanks Jem!
I was having a hard time, then out of the blue the ending music played - I had genuinely no idea I was that close to solving it! I'd only just figured out what to do with the theme, and used it to add in several tricky obstacles. I suppose things just snowballed without my noticing and ... bam!

This one started so easy including the theme, but attempts to win without lookups were impossible.   I love GARI but didn't know the word, don't know Paul PENA, had MYSIA instead of LYDIA, didn't know that UNIX came from Bell, and thought of tons of barn items but not PAILS.    That whole corner was just doom.

Super fun puzzle. The * clues were real clever.
I can do without another ENYA but seeing UNIX made me happy.
The only factoid I knew about MAZDA was their Wankel engines, so it's great to learn about another one.
Thank you Jem!

You totally got me on this one, Jem Burch! I way over or really under thought it and came in way above average. Deb gave me a clue so I was able to get LATINOS and remove TIN to get LAOS but then I had “We’re screwed” for WERESODEAD,

Assyria for LYDIA and Zircon for IRON which was the final nail in the coffin: the IRONY of it all(Also thought NY might be about New York)! 

And why did I keep trying to say NEVADA was Nebraska(with a Rebus)? Lol. You made me laugh.

What a great bounce back after yesterday's puzzle. I have to admit, even though I got the revealer in the first pass, it didn't make any sense to me. I solved 3 theme clues logically (the words fit) even though they made no sense whatsoever. I was 75% of the way through before I had that AHA! moment and everything fell into place, which is always very satisfying and the best part of a theme crossword. A very clever theme with some very witty clues (prose pro's job, might get splints, things found in bars) and fun sayings (WE'RE SO DEAD, EATS IT). Definitely left me with a smile on my face.

In an actual zero sum game, eventually someone ends up losing it all to someone else.

To be fair, all economic systems with currency are a zero sum game, as somebody having a unit of currency means somebody else can't have it at the same time.

@Helen Wright 

"Server" is favored by some in the US because it is seen as gender-neutral.  If you say "waiter", it is understood to be a man; a woman is a "waitress".  Since there's no such thing as a "servress", "server" is used without regard to gender, and some think that's important.

I have a female friend who is a (non-famous) thespian, who insists on being called an "actor", following a recent trend of using that word gender-neutrally.  She hates being called an "actress", as if it were some sort of terrible slander.  Meanwhile, the various award shows call their awards "Best Actor" for men and "Best Actress" for women.

If she wants to be an "actor", fine with me.  I don't think it (or the nomenclature for restaurant workers) matters that much to most people.

But here in the US, alongside "server", we still commonly say "waiter" and "waitress", and what they do is "wait tables"; "serving" is too broad a category here without further context.  After all, they could be playing tennis, sitting on a jury, or fulfilling a military obligation.

And some people find "serving" a little too...servile.

@Andrzej 
The verb “to wait” isn’t itself gendered, so it’s’ still used even if the nouns “waiter”/“waitress” are (quasi-)outdated. Collectively, “waitstaff” is generally considered fine, I believe.
Thank you all 🙂

@Steve L 

"I don't think it (or the nomenclature for restaurant workers) matters that much to most people." 

I use the term "server " because it matters to the people who have those jobs. 

While I don't disagree on its face with your premise about actors and actresses, that is an entirely different industry, and dare I say one where gender distinctions can matter for the job itself. (Of course there's the trope of actors being waiters, but I digress!)

Not only does "server" remove an unnecessary gender focus, "waitress" is especially gendered -- and stereotyped. 

As for being "too broad a category here without further context," try having the job title of "designer", as I do. Talk about ridiculously broad to the point of uselessness! Being a tennis player -- nor the other examples you provided -- are actual jobs, using the *noun* of "server". Maybe a "process server"? I only have ever seen it with the defining adjective...
@G  But "busser" means someone who kisses!

@HeathieJ

@Caroline Kearney That's why I said it gets lost in translation! ☺️ (With apologies for the typo... list for lost.) But the dictionary definition _is_ for a person who clears and resets tables... One example: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/busser

@Helen Wright 

On the off-chance you venture back here... 

When I bussed tables, it was at a large, multi-level restaurant in an historic building without a dumbwaiter: servers carried plated food by hand up and down stairs, but we were allowed buckets to clear the tables. 

I worked plenty of other restaurant jobs, and typically that busser position doesn't exist (except in film-borne imagination!). As you say, it's up to the front-of-house staff to do that work. Wasps buzzing around a pint glass: shudder! Not something I'd care for, either!

@Andrzej 
It might be weird for you because the puzzle mixes emotions, events and slang. There are wedding, birthday, etc. cards but there is no card that is specifically called a "love" card. Congrats threw me for a bit because I use congratulations, only.

Strands #347
“It's in the cards”
🔵🔵🔵🟡
🔵💡🔵🔵

I took a hint because I got tired of trying to untangle Love and Sympathy in the lower left.

@Mark 

The only cards I've ever sent were vacation postcards, very popular here up to the 90s. I've never heard of a baby card. I'm glad to see you say love card - which confused me, too - is not really a thing. Also, sympathy card?

@Andrzej
Greeting cards are very common in the USA. They aren’t quite as popular as they once were, but the variety is much greater. There are Valentines (or Valentine’s cards) rather than “love” cards. Sympathy cards are sent to the family of one who has died.

@Mark 

Ah, ok. The sympathy expressed to bereaved people is called "kondolencje" here, so I thought it might be condolences in English. Apparently it's the more generic "sympathy".

@Andrzej

Condolence and sympathy are synonymous, however printed cards usually use sympathy. If one is extending one’s feelings, my condolences is usual.

@SusanEM From the sporting world in American parlance, a "bye" is a round in a tournament bracket where a top seed (higher ranked) team doesn't have to play a game, hence it's a perk as they get more rest.
@SusanEM BYES are weeks when top-seeded teams don't have games scheduled in the playoffs. They get an extra week while the wild-card teams compete.

@John 
"animate" divided into "masculine" and "feminine," and took a bunch of inanimate nouns along with it....

That actually explains a lot. I always wondered about the arbitrary-seeming gender choices for certain inanimate nouns in English. Even more so in French. 

Thank you for your digression!

@John 
For me, it was reading a lot of military history. For example, knowing that DARI was the language spoken by fighters in the Afghan Northern Alliance, as opposed to Pashto, which is spoken in the south. And then knowing about the Plain of Jars in LAOS, where the Air Force dropped many tons of cluster bombs in an effort to interdict the Ho Chi Minh Trail. The prehistoric stone jars mostly survived that effort, but it's difficult to visit the sites because there are still millions of unexploded munitions. NZAID is leading the effort to clear them, and it's now a UNESCO world heritage site. (That was my rabbit hole.)

But I digress.

Anyway, LA(TIN)OS finally tipped me off to the gimmick, although I was suspicious of the GOLD answer. Once I let go of PLEADing, I was good to go. (Because "ding" was the bell sound.)

@Bill Yes, there are several theories -- the (very readable, and easy to find online) article I read is "The origin of the Proto-Indo-European gender system: Typological considerations," by Silvia Luraghi.

I'm always amazed by the story of how linguists predicted the existence of Proto-IE laryngeals from other sound change correspondences in other languages (even though none of these languages retained the laryngeals)...and were vindicated when Hittite texts were deciphered. Rather like the dog that didn't bark in that Sherlock Holmes mystery.
